 A free country
 
 In light of the recent letters concerning Intelligent Design versus evolution, I would like to mention one fundamental point. This is a free country. You are free to believe what you wish, as am I. You are free to live your life according to your beliefs, as am I.
 
 Indeed, it is where our joint interest is concerned that the problem arises.
 
 It was the hope of the founding fathers that the United States not become embroiled and divided by religious conflicts that had caused so much bloodshed in Europe, yet here we are, divided anyway.
 
 The founders were trying to establish a secular state. There are a huge number of religions in the world, 22 claiming 500,000 believers or more. People from all of those religions are welcome here. Our country and its schools need to be secular enough to treat people from all religions equally.
 
 That is why Christianity cannot be promoted in our public schools.
 
 Dana Howell
 Midland City

Friday, December 2, 2005
 
 Christian origins
 
 Each day I read the letters that are sent in to the editor by my fellow citizens. Some are enlightening, some are amusing and then there are the few that are absolutely outrageous.
 
 On Nov. 11, I once again was faced with the outrageous and knew I must respond. I am not quite sure where letter writer Dana Howell found her information on our founding fathers and their intentions concerning religion, but I feel it my duty as an American to set the record straight.
 
 The Mayflower Compact of 1620 stated "Having undertaken, for the glory of God, and advancement of the Christian faith ..."

 Our first president, George Washington, said that it is impossible to rightly govern without God and Bible.

Tuesday, December 20, 2005
 
 A look at history
 
 With regard to Donna Windham's Dec. 2 letter, I'd like to start by pointing out that this country was not founded in 1620 with the Mayflower Compact. The only true founding document of our nation is the Constitution, which wasn't written until 1789. And unlike the mere Mayflower Compact, the nation-founding Constitution is a secular document, not mentioning Jesus, God or Christianity, and with its only two references to religion being restrictions on the government.
 
 The first restriction is, "... no religious Test shall ever be required as a Qualification to any Office or public Trust under the United States." Soon after the U.S. Constitution's ratification, most states began to remove - voluntarily - their own "religious tests" from their state Constitutions.
 
 The second restrictions (the Establishment and Free Exercise clauses) are contained in the First Amendment. In 1802 Thomas Jefferson explained that their intent was to erect a "wall of separation between church and state." Jefferson also authored Virginia's 1786 Act for Establishing Religious Freedom, which served as a basis for the Constitution's method of handling religion.
 
 Ms. Windham quotes James Madison, the "father" of our Constitution, to support her views. While it is true that Madison was a Christian, he was against legislating religion onto others; not even he would have founded this as a Christian nation.
 
 In 1785, while opposing a religious bill, Madison wrote, "It degrades from the equal rank of Citizens all those whose opinions in Religion do not bend to those of the Legislative authority. Distant as it may be in its present form from the Inquisition, it differs from it only in degree."
 
 Finally, in 1797 the President of the United States, John Adams, signed the Treaty of Tripoli, which stated, "... the government of the United States is not, in any sense, founded on the Christian religion ...".
 
 Rick Pierson
 Dothan

Sunday January 8, 2006
 
 A note on history
 
 In response to Rick Pierson's Dec. 20 letter to the editor, I wish to make some comments.
 
 The letter is well written and it sets forth with clarity the secularists' world view in part and in particular their view of the establishment of our form of government. However, it is fraught with historical inaccuracies.
 
 Our constitution was written in the hot summer of 1787, not in 1789 as Mr. Pierson writes. While it does not mention the word "God" or "Jesus," as he rightly avers, it does conclude with the words, "Done in Convention by the Unanimous Consent of the States present the Seventeenth Day of September in the year of our LORD (all caps mine) one thousand seven hundred and eighty-seven...."
 
 What Lord does Mr. Pierson think the founders meant? If he could ask all of them, they would give him a name he and other secularists try to blot out at Christmastime.
 
 Further, Mr. Pierson quotes a statement attributed to President John Adams in the Treaty of Tripoli. What he doesn't say is he is quoting from a transcript copy of the document, not the original document, since it is nowhere to be found.
 
 Historians are still discussing whether or not the words attributed to President Adams were in the original document since an earlier transcript copy than the one Mr. Pierson quotes does not include those words.
 
 It is thought by some historians - and not without good reason - that the words, "...the government of the United States is not in any sense, founded on the Christian religion...", were inserted by someone other than John Adams at a later date.
 
 But if the words were in the original document, they do not mean what secularists construe them to mean. John Adams simply meant the United States did not have an established Christian Church as Great Britain had at the time.
 
 One final fact that Mr. Pierson misses: Our Union dates back to Oct. 14, 1774, when the delegates to the First Continental Congress issued the Declaration and Resolves of the First Continental Congress.
 
 Mike Greer
 Midland City
 

 
 I've sent off the following reply: don't know if or when it will get printed.
 
 
In his Jan. 8 letter, Mike Greer's desperate attempts to prop up the "Christian Nation" fallacy fail.
 
 He tries to redirect our focus to a document from 1774. But we were still ruled by England at that time: has Mr. Greer forgotten about the Declaration of Independence (1776) and the Revolutionary War, which didn't end until 1783? 
 
 The document that founded our nation is the US Constitution, and it is secular. What about, as Mr. Greer points out, its being dated "in the year of our Lord"?
 
 That phraseology was used out of tradition. That's how official documents were dated back then; in fact, it's still used more than 200 years later. My college diploma - granted by a secular, public university - also uses "year of our Lord" to date it. That phrase does not make my diploma a Christian document, nor my alma mater a Christian institution. 
 
 Further, our Constitution specifies days of the week using pagan-based traditions. Sunday, for example, was named in honor of the pagan Sun god. Would Mr. Greer therefore argue that the Constitution's use of "Sunday" makes it a pagan document, that founds a pagan nation? 
 
 Mr. Greer seems unaware of the wide ranging effects the Enlightenment had on the 1780s. Jefferson did not accept the divinity of Jesus; neither did Franklin, Ethan Allen, Thomas Paine, or many others. If we were to ask all of the great historical figures of that day about their beliefs in God we would not receive the unanimous Christian reply Mr. Greer presupposes.
 
 Finally, contra Mr. Greer, the version of the Treaty of Tripoli that President Adams and the Senate approved in 1797 was Joel Barlow's English translation, which did state, "... the government of the United States is not, in any sense, founded on the Christian religion ...".
 
 Rick Pierson
 Dothan

 Those men who would later be known as our founding fathers sponsored the publication of the Bible, imposed Christian morality on the armed forces and granted public lands to promote Christianity among the Indians, which, to me, shows our country was founded under the Christian faith.
 
 Mr. Pierson quoted Virginia's 1786 Act for Established Religious Freedom, however he failed to quote the first passage in that document, "Well aware that Almighty God hath created the mind free ..."

 Today's laws are directly derived from the Ten Commandments, our money says "In God we trust" and, like it or not, we are still referred to as "One Nation Under God." We are members of a free country, free to believe what we want, free to live the way we want and free to say anything we want.

I'm probably wasting my breath here, as this thread seems to have degenerated into the usual left/right slagging match, but I'll actually make a reply related to the thread topic ( emoticon_wow ).
 
 I think it is worth pointing out that the America colonies were not just a refuge for Puritans at all. The Mayflower in 1620 was already a full 35 years after the first (failed) colony of Roanoke. Roanoke was in no way a religious colony, it was established for economic and strategic reasons, essentially as a base for 'new world wealth'.
 
 Jamestown, the fist successful colony in 1607, was similarly founded for economic reasons. The London Company was just that, a company. The colony was controlled by shareholders and set up for the purpose of bringing wealth back to the mother country.
 
 Yes, a full 13 years later a bunch of puritans turned up as well. Does that mean that early Colonial America was a Christian venture? For the most part of course not. It was an economic venture. This modern belief that it was the former is a large distortion at best.
 
 That said it is undeniable that the colonist saw themselves as Christian, and their land as Christendom. God was seen as a integral part of every day life for them, Puritan or not. But as DamEtel points out, that is not to say they are right. I doubt even the most rabid of us would agree with many of the views these people had of the world. Yes they were in many ways admirable for their achievements, but that is not to say that they were infallible. They were very much products of their time, and had all the bigotry and short sightedness of it, in some cases more. People should realise that before they spout out the founding fathers as a valid reason against secularisation today.
